_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Auto. shutoff at 85%, min. class 1 Div. 1 electric w/in 5 ft. of all transfer (truck offloading) points w/Class 1 Div. 2 from 5-15 feet, Class 1 Div. 2 w/in 15 ft. of remainder.

_exec_summary.SummaryText: ely with our neighbors to ensure the health, environment, safety and security of Tulsa Terminal and the surrounding community.

ION PROGRAMS

Holly Energy Partners, L.P.'s accidental release prevention programs and emergency planning and response programs help effectively manage the hazards posed by the facility's regulated substance to employees/contractors, the public, and the environment. The covered process is regulated by the EPA RMP regulation 40 CFR Part 68 and the OSHA Process Safety Management Standard 29CFR 1910.119. 

The following accident prevention programs are in place at the Tulsa Terminal:

1) Employee Participation,
2) Process Safety Information,
3) Process Hazard Analysis (PHA),
4) Standard Operating Procedures,
5) Operator Training,
6) Contractors,
7) Pre-startup Safety Review,
8) Mechanical Integrity,
9) Hazardous Work Authorization (Hot Work, etc.),
10) Management of Change,
11) Incident Investigation,
12) Emergency Procedures/Planning,
13) Compliance Audits, and
14) Trade Secrets.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Tulsa Terminal has had no accidents (as defined in 40 CFR Part 68.42) within the past five (5) years.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Tulsa Terminal Emergency Response Plan provides the essential planning and training for protecting employees, the public, and the environment during emergency situations. Contained within the Plan are written procedures that outline the actions to be taken for various types of emergencies that could occur in the facility. These emergencies may include: airborne releases of chemical substances, spills to the water or ground, fires, explosions, personnel medical emergencies.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Holly Energy Partners, L.P. is continually striving to make Tulsa Terminal the safest and most reliable workplace possible for its employees, neighbors and community. The facility's focus is safe, reliable, and environmentally sound operations. The goal of the Tulsa Terminal is to demonstrate continuous improvement in its health, environmental and safety performance. In addition, Holly Energy Partners, L.P. will work cooperativ

Holly Energy Partners, L.P.
Tulsa Terminal

RMP EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The Holly Energy Partners, L.P. - Tulsa Terminal in Tulsa, OK is committed to providing a safe work environment for employees and to being a responsible corporate citizen. Holly Energy Partners, L.P. believes that excellent performance in the areas of health, environment, safety and security goes hand-in-hand with operational excellence and financial success. In fulfilling this commitment, Tulsa Terminal will comply with regulatory requirements and provide and maintain a safe working environment using acceptable and proven business practices. All Holly Energy Partners, L.P. employees will strive to identify and eliminate hazards which could result in injury and illness, damage to the environment, property damage, and security losses.

Tulsa Terminal is operated and maintained in a manner that protects the environment, as well as the health and safety of employees, contractors, and the community in which it operates. Holly Energy Partners, L.P. promotes health, safety, and the environment through programs of awareness, compliance, prevention and protection. These programs include a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning. This summary provides a brief overview of the risk management activities that we have designed and implemented.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

Holly Energy Partners, L.P. - Tulsa Terminal is a light products, bulk petroleum storage facility used in the storage and distribution of petroleum products to retail and commercial end-users in the vicinity of Tulsa, OK. The Terminal handles and stores various grades of unleaded gasoline, low-diesel fuel, and additives.  The Risk Management plan applies to the Butane Blending Process operated at Tulsa Terminal in which butane is offloaded from trucks, stored in pressurized storage vessels, and blended into gasoline lines as gasoline trucks are being filled.
